questions.question: High-speed storage interface connecting SSDs directly to the motherboard.
questions.explanation: NVMe uses PCIe lanes for extremely fast storage access.

questions.question: Chip on the motherboard managing data flow between CPU, memory, and peripherals.
questions.explanation: The chipset determines motherboard capabilities and compatibility.

questions.question: Technology allowing a CPU core to handle two instruction threads simultaneously.
questions.explanation: Hyper-Threading improves CPU efficiency through simultaneous multithreading.

questions.question: The bus connecting the CPU to memory for data transfer.
questions.explanation: FSB determines the speed of communication between CPU and RAM.

questions.question: ROM chip containing firmware for booting and hardware initialization.
questions.explanation: EEPROM stores BIOS or UEFI firmware that can be updated.

questions.question: Power management standard allowing the OS to control device power states.
questions.explanation: ACPI enables features like sleep mode and power management.

questions.question: Process of loading a small program that then loads the full operating system.
questions.explanation: Bootstrapping is the multi-stage boot process starting from firmware.

questions.question: The physical connection point on the motherboard for the CPU.
questions.explanation: CPU sockets vary by manufacturer and determine CPU compatibility.

questions.question: Memory controller managing communication between CPU and RAM.
questions.explanation: Modern CPUs have integrated memory controllers for faster access.

questions.question: Process of adjusting hardware settings beyond manufacturer specifications for better performance.
questions.explanation: Overclocking increases clock speeds but may reduce stability and lifespan.
